articles.headline: Nightclub Massacre in Istanbul Exposes Turkey’s Deepening Fault Lines
articles.snippet: The attack on Sunday, which killed at least 39 people, targeted a symbol of a cosmopolitan Istanbul that is increasingly under threat.
articles.abstract: The attack on Sunday, which killed at least 39 people, targeted a symbol of a cosmopolitan Istanbul that is increasingly under threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — When a lone gunman murdered dozens of New Year’s revelers early Sunday, he targeted a symbol of a cosmopolitan Istanbul that is increasingly under threat: a dazzling nightclub where people from around the world could party together, free from the mayhem and violence gripping the region.

articles.headline: With New Congress Poised to Convene, Obama’s Policies Are in Peril
articles.snippet: The most powerful and ambitious Republican-led Congress in 20 years plans quick action on several priorities — most notably to clear a path for the repeal of President Obama’s health care law.
articles.abstract: The most powerful and ambitious Republican-led Congress in 20 years plans quick action on several priorities — most notably to clear a path for the repeal of President Obama’s health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The most powerful and ambitious Republican-led Congress in 20 years will convene Tuesday, with plans to leave its mark on virtually every facet of American life — refashioning the country’s social safety net, wiping out scores of labor and environmental regulations and unraveling some of the most significant policy prescriptions put forward by the Obama administration.

articles.headline: The Best Time to Retune Your Career? It’s Probably Right Now
articles.snippet: Thinking about asking for a raise, or changing jobs, or just want to be more happy at work? Here's advice on how to get started.
articles.abstract: Thinking about asking for a raise, or changing jobs, or just want to be more happy at work? Here's advice on how to get started.
articles.lead_paragraph: January is the big month for buying gym memberships. The excesses of the holiday season leave many of us looking to make improvements in our lives — a search that often leads straight to the elliptical machine.

articles.headline: In Year of Anti-Muslim Vitriol, Brands Promote Inclusion
articles.snippet: A slew of major American companies prominently featured everyday Muslim men, women and children in their marketing last year.
articles.abstract: A slew of major American companies prominently featured everyday Muslim men, women and children in their marketing last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gentle piano music starts as the doorbell chimes. A white-haired Christian pastor greets his friend, a Muslim imam, and the two converse and laugh over a cup of tea, wincing about their creaky knees as they prepare to part ways. Later, it spurs the same idea in each for a gift: kneepads sent via Amazon Prime. (It is a commercial, after all.)

articles.headline: The Afghan War and the Evolution of Obama
articles.snippet: A strategy that went from a “good war” to the shorthand “Afghan good enough” reflects the president’s coming to terms with what was possible in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: A strategy that went from a “good war” to the shorthand “Afghan good enough” reflects the president’s coming to terms with what was possible in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s advisers wrestled with an intractable problem in the spring and summer of 2015: How could they stabilize Afghanistan while preserving Mr. Obama’s longtime goal of pulling out the last American troops before he left office?

articles.headline: Google Helping Mobile Publishing? Some Publishers Are Not So Sure
articles.snippet: AMP, a method of loading of mobile web pages more quickly, has raised concern among small publishers worried they are losing control of their content.
articles.abstract: AMP, a method of loading of mobile web pages more quickly, has raised concern among small publishers worried they are losing control of their content.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last month, Federico Viticci, who runs MacStories, a news site devoted to Apple and its products, made a change in how the site publishes articles for mobile gadgets. MacStories, he declared, would no longer support a Google-backed method for faster loading of mobile web pages, called AMP.

articles.headline: A Turntable Reborn Turns Its Back on Its Hip-Hop Legacy
articles.snippet: Panasonic has reintroduced its Technics SL-1200, long prized by D.J.s, but is marketing it to a different crowd: audiophiles who won’t blink at its $2,800 price tag.
articles.abstract: Panasonic has reintroduced its Technics SL-1200, long prized by D.J.s, but is marketing it to a different crowd: audiophiles who won’t blink at its $2,800 price tag.
articles.lead_paragraph: UTSUNOMIYA, Japan — In the sofa-appointed listening room of a factory north of Tokyo, hi-fi fans can listen to vintage vinyl records on a sound system costing $45,000, including a sleek silver turntable. Musical choices include rock — the Eagles’ “Hotel California,” sounding warm and vivid through four-foot-tall speakers — jazz and classical.

articles.headline: Ailing Vermont Town Pins Hopes on Mideast Refugees
articles.snippet: Some residents of Rutland, Vt., see the expected arrival of 100 refugees as an economic boon, while others are not as optimistic.
articles.abstract: Some residents of Rutland, Vt., see the expected arrival of 100 refugees as an economic boon, while others are not as optimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: RUTLAND, Vt. — They hustled into the church on a biting winter evening, unburdened themselves of scarves and gloves, and settled into pews to sound out words in Arabic.

articles.headline: As Scandal Roils South Korea, Fingers Point to Mixing of Politics and Business
articles.snippet: Outrage over President Park Geun-hye’s actions has turned to broader concerns over the power of the presidency and its relationship with conglomerates.
articles.abstract: Outrage over President Park Geun-hye’s actions has turned to broader concerns over the power of the presidency and its relationship with conglomerates.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — The heir apparent to the Samsung empire, Jay Y. Lee, was trying to push through a corporate merger seen as critical to his plans to succeed his father as chairman.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
